title: 106_s2839
content: The "Marriage Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2000" eliminates the marriage penalty in standard deduction. The "Marriage Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2000" eliminates the marriage penalty in standard deduction by amending section 63(c) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendments include adjusting the dollar amount and making technical changes to ensure proper application of the code. The "Marriage Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2000" eliminates the marriage penalty in standard deduction by amending section 63(c) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000. The Marriage Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2000 eliminates the marriage penalty in the 15-percent and 28-percent rate brackets. The Marriage Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2000 eliminates the marriage penalty in the 15-percent and 28-percent rate brackets by adjusting tax tables to prevent tax increases due to inflation. The table in subsection (a) determines the applicable percentage of taxable income based on tables in subsections (c) and (d), with the latter being half of the former. The applicable percentage is determined according to a specific table for tax purposes. The applicable percentage for taxable years starting in 2002 and beyond is specified in a table, with amounts rounded to the nearest multiple of $50. Amendments to the tax code include changes to the marriage penalty phaseout and rate brackets. Effective starting from taxable years after December 31, 2001. Marriage penalty relief for earned income credit is addressed in Section 4 of the tax code amendments. The tax code amendments provide marriage penalty relief for the earned income credit by increasing the phaseout amount for joint returns by $2,500. Additionally, there is an inflation adjustment based on the cost-of-living for the taxable year. The tax code amendments increase the phaseout amount for joint returns by $2,500 and provide inflation adjustment based on the cost-of-living for the taxable year. The amendments apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000. SEC. 5. Preserve family tax credits from the alternative minimum tax. Section 26 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to limit the aggregate amount of credits allowed for the taxable year. This limitation is based on the taxpayer's regular tax liability reduced by the foreign tax credit and the tax imposed by section 55(a). Conforming amendments are made to sections 24, 32, and 904 of the Code. Section 904 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended by redesignating subsections (i), (j), and (k) as subsections (h), (i), and (j) respectively, with an effective date for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001. The amendments made by this Act will cease to apply after September 30, 2005, except for certain provisions which will not apply after December 31, 2004.
